from my POV, using inline client-side "templates" for URIs or entity
bodies=
 makes sense when the problem domain you are implementing has a
substantial=
ly high number of variables for either URIs and/or entity
bodies _and_ you =
want to inform clients at runtime of the possible
options for URIs and.or b=
odies..

HTML took on the task of providing both URI and entity bodie
termp=
lates by providing the exact same mechanism:  HTML.FORM, but
adding a singl=
e "switch". that is, for HTML.FORM@method=3D"get", client
apps are to treat=
 the FORM as a URI template; otherwise, the client
apps are to treat the FO=
RM as an entity body template.

Atom solved this problem by dropping suppor=
t for templates completely;
servers simply have no way (as defined by Atom/=
AtomPub) to inform
clients at runtime of any state-transfer option details =
(other than
identified links such as rel=3D"edit", etc.). this works fine f=
or
problem domains where the options are either non-existent, or the list
o=
f options are simple/stable enough to hard-code all details of each
and eve=
ry possible option (including _when_ these options are valid)
into the clie=
nt apps directly.

while it's true that machine-only clients (i.e. no activ=
e human in the
driver seat) have additional work to do when supporting temp=
lating, i
rarely find this "additional work" is wasted energy. i've been ab=
le to
use HTML.FORMs to very good effect in M2M scenarios several times.
th=
is works especially well when the _vocabulary_ of the problem domain
is sta=
ble, while the _workflow_ options of the problem domain are
variable/custom=
izable. IOW, machines do not need to learn *new
variables* over time, but i=
nstead need to learn *new collections* of
the same variables (i.e. the numb=
er of FORMs encountered and the list
of variables in each FORM changes over=
 time, but none of these changes
introduces *unknown* variables to the mach=
ine).
